One blog ends, another begins http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/20.html#a1069 This blog is moving. Almost exactly four years ago, on July 22, 2002, I started my first blog. Blogging felt natural to me since I'd been writing for the Web since 1994 and self-publishing since 1974 (originally via mimeograph). My blog was part of a larger blogging program I'd put together at Salon, in partnership with Userland. It was the tech-downturn doldrums -- an era when every time we at Salon opened the papers or fired up our browsers we knew that someone, somewhere, would be predicting our imminent demise. And there wasn't a lot of extra cash at the company at the time, so the blogs program was chiefly a labor of love, launched in the wee hours. I did the CSS, wrangling Salon's home-page design into Radio Userland templates, all by myself (which anyone who knows anything about CSS can probably tell with a single glance at the unruly code). I loved Radio Userland at the time for the way it combined a blog publishing system and an RSS reader. But times change; Userland put its energy into other products; Salon Blogs produced many great blogs but not a substantial change in Salon's business; and my blog settled down from the program's focal point to a personal-publishing bullhorn. Several months ago, in anticipation of Salon's plan to build a new platform for users to contribute their own writing, we closed off new signups to the old Salon Blogs platform. Today I'm moving my own blog to a new home, here, at Wordyard. I've managed to export my whole four years' worth of archives (over 1000 posts, averaging about one per weekday for the whole timespan) to Wordpress. (For those who care, I used the Radio Userland exporter, which pops out a plaintext file in Movable Type export format; edited that file to make things like titles and categories work; then imported into Wordpress.) The comments, alas, will remain back at the original Salon Blogs location, where they will continue to be available. With this move, I plan to blog somewhat more vigorously, and to provide more posts about my forthcoming book, Dreaming in Code, as its January 2007 publish date nears. I also look forward to leveraging some of the great features and plugins created by the Wordpress open-source community. If you subscribe to my RSS feed in Bloglines (the reader I've been using daily for years), the transition should be transparent -- Bloglines will do the flip for you, you don't need to touch anything. If you subscribe through other feed readers or services, you'll have to resubscribe to the new feed address, which is here. More anon! http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/20.html#a1069 Thu, 20 Jul 2006 16:06:59 GMT http://rcs.salon.com/rcsComments/comments?u=14&p=1069&link=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.salon.com%2F0000014%2F2006%2F07%2F20.html%23a1069

Stem cells: Bush's shameful first veto? http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/19.html#a1068 President Bush appears poised for the first veto of his presidency. The cause that has finally pushed him to reject Congressional legislation? An attempt to expand funding for stem cell research that Bush hobbled back in 2001. For millions of Americans, the potential fruits of stem cell research -- in the form of cures to dangerous diseases -- are a serious matter with grave personal import. For President Bush, the issue has always served as a political football. On the one hand, Bush argues that the destruction of human embryos (microscopic organisms made up of a few cells) is a kind of killing. His press spokesman, Tony Snow, adopting the supercharged cant of anti-abortion activists, referred to it recently as "murder." In order to stop such "murder," Bush agreed in 2001 to limit all federal funding of stem cell research to a handful of pre-existing "lines" of cells -- cells that had been created specifically for research. His argument was, let's not use tax dollars to pay for the destruction of more embryos for the sake of research. Here is why Bush's position is a joke: Thousands and thousands of embryos are destroyed every year in fertility clinics. They are created in petri dishes as part of fertility treatments like IVF; then they are discarded. If Bush and his administration truly believe that destroying an embryo is a kind of murder, they shouldn't be wasting their time arguing about research funding: They should immediately shut down every fertility clinic in the country, arrest the doctors and staff who operate them, and charge all the wannabe parents who have been wantonly slaughtering legions of the unborn. But of course they'll never do such a thing. (Nor, to be absolutely clear, do I think they should.) Bush could not care less about this issue except as far as it helps burnish his pro-life credentials among his "base." This has been true since the first airing of Bush's position in 2001, as I said back then. So he finds a purely symbolic way of taking a stand, but won't follow the logic of his position to the place where it might cause him any political harm -- as opposing the family-building dreams of millions of middle-class Americans would doubtless do. (And please don't test our credulity with the laughable "Go ahead and do the research, but let's not spend taxpayers' money on things they don't believe in" argument: If that had any bearing, my tax dollars would not be funding a war that 2/3 of the country opposes now that the specious arguments used to launch it have collapsed.) If Bush believes destroying embryos is murder, let him take a real stand against it. If he doesn't, he shouldn't make it harder for the thousands of embryos that are being discarded anyway to be used for a valuable purpose that could improve real lives. That's why Bush's stem cell position isn't Solomonic -- it's craven. His upcoming veto is an act not of moral leadership but of hypocrisy. And the cost of this hypocrisy, assuming Congress can't muster the votes for an override, will be borne by everyone who dreams of new cures for awful illnesses. http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/19.html#a1068 Wed, 19 Jul 2006 14:49:04 GMT http://rcs.salon.com/rcsComments/comments?u=14&p=1068&link=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.salon.com%2F0000014%2F2006%2F07%2F19.html%23a1068

Sonic middle age: Everybody's happy nowadays http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/13.html#a1067 I'm knocked out, stunned, by the new Sonic Youth album, Rather Ripped. I'm not one of the band's cultists. Over the years, from the mid-'80s on, I'd hear, from friends who were, that I was missing out: They'd tell me that whatever their latest album was -- "Daydream Nation"! "Goo"! -- it was the album that would persuade me to join their ranks. I'd listen, feel respect for the legendary New York art-noise band's work, but never feel like coming back for more.

So I've been out of the Sonic Youth orbit for a while. Maybe I missed some transformation or evolution; "Rather Ripped" is incredibly seductive -- just melodic enough to engage you, just experimental enough to keep you hitting "repeat." The guitars shimmer with lanky Lou Reed/Feelies lines; the lyrics are entirely audible; the incredibly tight rhythm section could do this in their sleep, but they're wide awake. There is a fundamental joy working its way out in this music, in a fully audible way. I am hooked.

In other musical events, the Mountain Goats are slated to release a new album, Get Lonely, next month. But if you are impatient, there is an EP from their Australian tour titled Babylon Springs that is also a fine piece of work. If some of the chord sequences sound a tad familiar, the full-band arrangements are sparkling, the lyrics sharp, the feelings painfully intense. http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/13.html#a1067 Fri, 14 Jul 2006 03:15:18 GMT http://rcs.salon.com/rcsComments/comments?u=14&p=1067&link=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.salon.com%2F0000014%2F2006%2F07%2F13.html%23a1067

Mashup Camp 2 http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/13.html#a1066 Yesterday I spent the day at Mashup Camp 2. I missed the first one last winter, but what I read intrigued me enough to make a point of showing up when it came around again.

The two relevant things here, one having to do with mashups, the other with that word "camp," which is really a proxy for the whole "unconference" movement of which this event is a high-profile example in the tech world. (Mashup Camp organizer David Berlind wrote about the first event's experience with the format back in February.) Let's start with that.

When I showed up at 9 a.m. down in Mountain View, at the Computer History Museum, the conference had no schedule -- just an open grid on an eight-foot-long pad at the front of the meeting hall. An hour later, several dozen developers (and some "API providers," a k a vendors or company reps) had introduced themselves, proposed sessions, posted the sessions on the grid, and presto, there it was, a conference schedule.

There had been no arguments over process, no disputes, no grandstanding or boring throat-clearing. Part of that was the result of deft moderation by Kaliya Hamlin (she writes about the event here); part, no doubt, was the nature of the attendees -- this was primarily an engineering conclave, after all. If we'd been talking about Iraq, something tells me the process might have been bumpier.

In the pop culture world, "mashup" means creating a new work by combining elements of two (or more) existing works. (Danger Mouse's "Grey Album" -- the Beatles' White Album meets Jay-Z's Black Album -- is probably the highest-profile example in music to date.) In software, a mashup is a new program or service created by wiring up two or more existing programs or services.

Web-services mashups can be remarkably easy to hack together and provide immediately gratifying results -- the canonical example was the Craigslist/GoogleMaps mashup that Paul Rademacher made last year, placing the Craigslist for-rent ads on Google's map service. At Mashup Camp, developers got the opportunity to show off their projects during a "Speed Geeking" event (modeled on speed dating) at which visitors in groups of a half-dozen wandered from table to table to hear five-minute demos. Here's a full list of the participating demo-ers.

I didn't come away with the sense that any one of the projects I saw was going to change the universe. But put it all together and you got a window onto a simpler, faster, and perhaps smarter approach to software product development -- one that trades in the virtue of from-the-ground-up consistency and thoroughness for the even more compelling virtue of "getting something working fast." It's software development as a Darwinian ocean in which large numbers of small projects are launched into the water. Only a handful will make it to land. But most of them required so little investment that the casualty rate is nothing to lose sleep over. http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/13.html#a1066 Thu, 13 Jul 2006 21:09:11 GMT http://rcs.salon.com/rcsComments/comments?u=14&p=1066&link=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.salon.com%2F0000014%2F2006%2F07%2F13.html%23a1066

Fallows, PIMs and Chandler http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/11.html#a1064 James Fallows has been writing thoughtfully about computer software for longer than most of us have been using it. Years ago he wrote a definitive paean (long online here but apparently no longer) to Lotus Agenda, Mitch Kapor's legendary personal information manager. (I say "a" rather than "the" because this program evoked such loyalty from smart writers it actually ended up with two definitive paeans; the other was by Jimmy Guterman.)

In the new issue of the Atlantic, Fallows writes about two latter-day PIMs -- Microsoft's OneNote and Chandler, the long-gestating project of Kapor's Open Source Applications Foundation, the tale of which forms the central narrative of my book, Dreaming in Code. He interviewed me for the article; though most of our conversation wound up on the cutting-room floor, I did make it into one paragraph. I wish the article were online (there's a stub here, but the full piece is only accessible to subscribers). But I couldn't ask for a better venue for my first distant-early-warning book publicity. Here's the relevant graph:

  Despite substantial follow-up grants from foundations and universities, the team developing Chandler has so far released only a partly functional calendar application. Scott Rosenberg, of Salon magazine, became an "embedded journalist" on the Chandler project from 2003 to 2005 in order to investigate why good software is so hard to make. (His book about Chandler and complex software design, Dreaming in Code, will be published in November [now, January]). "It is taking a long time, but anyone who writes off Chandler is being short-sighted," he told me. "They are on a quest."

Fallows asked me whether I thought the book had turned out to be a comedy or a tragedy.

"Neither," I replied, thinking furiously on my feet, my brain flashing back to my decade as a theater and movie critic. "It's an epic!" http://blogs.salon.com/0000014/2006/07/11.html#a1064 Wed, 12 Jul 2006 02:35:19 GMT http://rcs.salon.com/rcsComments/comments?u=14&p=1064&link=http%3A%2F%2Fblogs.salon.com%2F0000014%2F2006%2F07%2F11.html%23a1064

entry.title: NewsGator Continues International Expansion Through Partnership With Agrex to Provide Enterprise RSS Aggregation Solutions in Japan
entry.summary:
NewsGator Enterprise Server to Help Companies Improve Distribution of Localized, Relevant Information in World's Second Largest RSS Market

DENVER, CO and TOKYO--(MARKET WIRE)--Aug 14, 2006 -- NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced a multi-year partnership with Agrex, Inc., a leading IT services company based in Tokyo, Japan. Under the agreement, Agrex will provide a localized, behind-the-firewall version of the NewsGator Enterprise Server (NGES) to Japanese companies looking to improve the way they find, disseminate and view information through the use of RSS technology. Japanese companies can use NGES to streamline the process of information delivery within their organizations, increase employee productivity and reduce IT resource requirements.

NewsGator had previously announced an agreement with GMO Group to provide a hosted version of NGES in this market. Japan is currently the world's second largest market in terms of blog and RSS-related activity, according to market measurement firm Technorati.

"Today's agreement continues to broaden our leadership position beyond North America and provides an opportunity for Japanese businesses to take advantage of the powerful capabilities that NGES offers," said Sandy Hamilton, executive vice president of NewsGator Technologies. "Agrex is a well-respected provider of IT services to the enterprise market in Japan, and through this partnership, they can help Japanese businesses increase efficiency and improve the delivery of relevant information."

"NewsGator has already established itself as the market leader in North America, helping companies solve the increasing problem of how to better manage the flow of content and information throughout their organizations," said Masao Ueno, president of Agrex, Inc. "By partnering with NewsGator, we are able to harness its world class technology and success in deploying RSS solutions to businesses and deliver the benefits of enterprise RSS to the Japanese market."

About NewsGator Enterprise Server

NewsGator Enterprise Server is a revolutionary new product for aggregating, reading and distributing RSS content within the enterprise. It brings the power of NewsGator's robust RSS platform behind the firewall, providing enterprise class security, manageability and deployment. With its powerful search, collaboration and administrative capabilities, organizations can ensure that relevant information automatically gets delivered to employees. In addition, NGES optionally integrates with Microsoft Exchange and Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) servers such as Active Directory, which eases deployment for enterprise IT departments and provides a user interface that employees are comfortable with.

About NewsGator Technologies, Inc.

NewsGator Technologies is the world's leading RSS platform company. Headquartered in Denver, CO, NewsGator develops and markets RSS aggregation solutions for individual end users, enterprises and online content providers. Using NewsGator products and solutions, businesses and consumers can subscribe to news, information, podcasts and other relevant content more efficiently and effectively than with traditional channels. With NewsGator, users have access to RSS information via the Web, Microsoft Outlook, mobile devices and both Windows and Mac-based desktop clients. All NewsGator products synchronize seamlessly, enabling users to read their RSS feeds anywhere, anytime, with any device. For more information, visit www.newsgator.com.

About Agrex, Inc.

Agrex was established in 1965 and is a comprehensive data utility company consisting mainly of business process outsourcing, software solutions and system integration. For more information, visit http://www.agrex.co.jp/.

Denver, CO -- Aug. 9, 2006 -- Last night, NewsGator released beta versions of new toolbars for Firefox and Internet Explorer. These toolbars allow you to extend the NewsGator experience directly into the browsers. Key features include:

Discovery of and subscription to new feeds, straight from your browser, into NewsGator Online, NewsGator Inbox, or FeedDemon.

Autodiscovery of feeds as you browse the web and get information - like the number of NewsGator subscribers – or preview the feed before you subscribe.

entry.title: NewsGator Brings Podcasts and Other Content to Yahoo! Messenger
entry.summary:
Unique RSS-based Application Allows Users to Access Audio and Video Podcasts, and Other Content From Around the Web

Denver, CO – July 31, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced a new RSS plug-in for the Yahoo!? Messenger with Voice real-time communications suite. NewsGator for Yahoo! Messenger with Voice allows users to access audio and video podcasts as well as other content from around the Web through an IM interface. Thousands of people have already downloaded the plug-in since its beta release last month.

Plug-ins offer consumers a way to further personalize IM and collaborate with their network of colleagues, family and friends. NewsGator for Yahoo! Messenger with Voice (referred to as “Podcasts & Buzz” on the Yahoo! Messenger Web site) allows users to check out the “Editor’s Choice” podcasts selected by NewsGator editors, or browse through podcasts and news content from different categories including entertainment, sports and technology. Users can also personalize their experience by creating a free NewsGator Online account to select and organize their own feeds, which are then delivered through their NewsGator IM plug-in.

“Integrating RSS capabilities into Yahoo! Messenger further demonstrates our market leadership and underscores our commitment to providing a great user experience on every platform – desktop, Web, Outlook, mobile, TV, and now IM,” said Greg Reinacker, CTO and founder of NewsGator. “Moving forward, we’ll continue to add support for more applications and devices, delivering relevant information, audio and video content to platforms selected by our users. This is all part of a concept we refer to as ‘NewsGator Everywhere.’ Wherever our users are and whatever device or application they are using, their chosen content will be available to them.”

The interface of the Podcasts and Buzz plug-in was designed in conjunction with Yahoo! to work within the common framework and user interface that instant messaging users are familiar with. With NewsGator and Yahoo! technology, users can sort content by audio, video and text categories, open a slide-out video window that provides a rich viewing experience and sharing options, organize content by topic for easy customization, and collapse or expand content sections to preserve on-screen content visibility.

NewsGator’s Podcasts and Buzz plug-in for Yahoo! Messenger with Voice is currently available in beta at the Yahoo Messenger plug-in download site, and the final version will be made available in the third quarter.

Entrepreneurial Canadian Law Firm Uses NewsGator Enterprise Server to Streamline Dissemination of Information and Encourage Collaboration

Denver, CO – July 19, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced that Goodman and Carr LLP has deployed NewsGator Enterprise Server (NGES) as the next-generation information dissemination platform for its employees. NewsGator provides Goodman and Carr with a more effective content delivery channel for internal and external information, enabling the firm’s employees to more easily access important content from their Microsoft SharePoint® Portal. Goodman and Carr is a full-service business law firm with 110 lawyers in Toronto, serving a diversified roster of national and international clients.

Through its built-in integration with SharePoint, NGES enables Goodman and Carr to deliver RSS feeds from LexisNexis and other external news sources directly to practice teams and individual employees via SharePoint Web Parts. The centralized management of content has improved the productivity of the firm’s attorneys, paralegals, clerks and other knowledge workers. In the near future, Goodman and Carr will give its teams the ability to collaborate through internal blogs and other social media tools and subscribe to that content through NGES.

“It is vital that our employees have immediate access to the latest research, news and information related to their current cases, clients, and legal and industry issues,” said Elizabeth Ellis, partner and chief knowledge officer at Goodman and Carr LLP. “NewsGator Enterprise Server helps provide employees with relevant information in a timely manner and enables the firm to collaborate more effectively. It has provided us with a more efficient and automated process for the distribution of this information, resulting in a more productive work environment at Goodman and Carr.”

“With NewsGator’s flexible RSS platform and out-of-the-box integration with Microsoft SharePoint, professional service firms like Goodman and Carr are able to utilize the power of RSS to dramatically improve knowledge management and business collaboration,” said A.V. “Sandy” Hamilton, NewsGator’s executive vice president of sales, marketing and business development. “NewsGator Enterprise Server brings RSS into the enterprise arena by offering companies the administrative controls and features that streamline the process of information delivery within their organizations and increase worker productivity.”

entry.title: NewsGator Honored by AlwaysOn in Top 100 Private Companies Awards
entry.summary:
Leading RSS Platform Company Named in Prestigious List Based on Innovation, Customer Adoption and Strategic Value

Denver, CO – July 12, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced that it has been chosen by AlwaysOn as one of the Top 100 Private Company award winners. NewsGator, which offers RSS aggregation solutions for consumers, enterprises, publishers and other online content providers, was selected by the AlwaysOn editorial panel based on a set of five criteria - technology innovation, market potential, customer adoption, media buzz and investor value creation.

entry.title: NewsGator Expands Into Asia by Partnering With GMO Group on Hosted RSS Aggregation Solution for the Enterprise
entry.summary:
NewsGator Enterprise Server Will Provide Localized RSS Feeds to Japanese Businesses Through Web-Based Service

DENVER, CO and TOKYO -- (MARKET WIRE) -- 06/06/2006 -- NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS Platform Company, today announced a multi-year partnership with GMO Internet Group, a leading Internet infrastructure and services company based in Tokyo, Japan. Under the agreement, GMO Internet Group will provide a localized, hosted version of the NewsGator Enterprise Server to Japanese companies looking to improve the way they find, disseminate and view information through the use of RSS technology in their everyday business activities. Japan is currently the world's second largest market in terms of blog and RSS-related activity, according to market measurement firm Technorati.

NewsGator is working closely with GMO Internet Group to build a customized, hosted version of the NewsGator Enterprise Server that meets the unique needs of Japanese companies, including a database of Japanese-specific RSS feeds. The service will also include NewsGator's recently introduced mobile capabilities, allowing employees to access the RSS aggregator while traveling and working remotely. The combined NewsGator/GMO service is expected to be available to customers in the third quarter of 2006 and will be the first localized, enterprise RSS solution to reach Japan.

NewsGator Enterprise Server is a business solution that allows timely and relevant RSS feeds to be delivered directly to employees via Microsoft Outlook®, Web browsers and mobile devices in a synchronized manner. Internal content (such as reports, executive communications and product information) and external content (such as competitive intelligence, customer data and industry developments) are aggregated in easy-to-use folders. Default subscriptions can be set up for employees, who can also choose to add other additional relevant feeds. Senior executives, marketing and communications professionals and knowledge workers can all save time and work smarter by harnessing the power of RSS.

"Asia is clearly a burgeoning Internet market and Japan has quickly embraced blogging and RSS technology, so it was natural for us to extend our leadership position in North America to that segment," said Sandy Hamilton, executive vice president of NewsGator Technologies. "By partnering with another market leader in GMO Internet Group, we expect to quickly penetrate the Japanese business community, allowing companies to take advantage of a localized RSS platform that improves information dissemination and consumption."

"NewsGator is the clear leader in RSS aggregation and we wanted to take advantage of their technology and market expertise to deliver a solution that meets the unique needs of Japanese corporations," said Masatoshi Kumagai, CEO of GMO Internet Group, a subsidiary of multi-billion dollar GMO Group. "Although in its infancy, RSS in the enterprise is quickly gaining traction in North America because of its ability to help companies better control and take advantage of Internet-based information and content. We're already seeing great anticipation from our customer base for this solution and look forward to unveiling it in this market."

entry.title: Spencer Stuart Selects NewsGator’s Enterprise RSS Solution to Improve Relevant Information Delivery
entry.summary:
Leading Executive Search Consulting Firm Implements NewsGator Enterprise Server to Improve Search Consultant Productivity

Denver, CO – June 5, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced that Spencer Stuart, one of the country’s largest and oldest executive search firms, has deployed NewsGator Enterprise Server (NGES) to improve the way its employees find and share information. The product enables its consultants and other employees to automatically track relevant information about clients, executives and industries they serve.

Through NGES, Spencer Stuart employees can access content from both internal (enterprise applications and repositories) and external (news and blogs) sources through NewsGator Enterprise Server and have it delivered through Microsoft Outlook® clients and Microsoft Sharepoint® portals. Later this year, the firm plans to automatically subscribe its search consultants and associates to all of the relevant RSS feeds they need regarding a company, its executives and news in the industry and have them be delivered directly to a folder in Microsoft Outlook. This will allow employees to receive the most relevant information they need to do their jobs without having to understand RSS.

"Delivering relevant, timely information in an easy-to-consume way is a challenge in most enterprises, but RSS is a great way to solve this problem," said Trapper Markelz, senior project manager at Spencer Stuart. "NewsGator’s product allows users to gather this information in an easy, manageable way."

"In today’s business environment, accessing content from a growing number of different sources can be an overwhelming and inefficient process," said A.V. "Sandy" Hamilton, NewsGator’s executive vice president of sales, marketing and business development. "Spencer Stuart understands the value proposition that NGES brings to the table by providing its consultants with the tools they need to stay on top of breaking market and company-specific news."

Why NewsGator Enterprise Server

Spencer Stuart selected NGES because it contains four features which allow it to immediately realize the benefits of RSS in the enterprise:

• Outlook/Exchange integration;

• Active directory integration;

• Cross-device/interface synchronization; and

• API access for programmatic subscribe/unsubscribe functions.

"Other offerings we researched couldn’t provide the comprehensive features of NewsGator," Markelz said. "NewsGator was the only company offering a full-featured, server-based aggregator that could live behind the firewall."

With its powerful search, collaboration and administrative capabilities, organizations can ensure that relevant information automatically gets delivered to employees. entry.title: NewsGator Technologies Releases New Version of Premier Platform for Enterprise RSS Management
entry.summary:
NewsGator Enterprise Server 1.3 Helps Companies Improve Aggregation and Distribution of Relevant Information

Denver, CO – May 30, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced the release of NewsGator Enterprise Server (NGES) 1.3, the latest version of its market-leading enterprise RSS aggregation and distribution platform. Since its initial introduction in October 2005, ten Fortune 100 companies as well as several market leaders in various industries have embraced NGES to streamline the process of information delivery within their organizations, increase employee productivity and discover untapped knowledge.

A behind-the-firewall, enterprise-class offering, NGES provides organizations with the most complete and flexible platform for finding, distributing and sharing only the most relevant RSS feeds across groups and organizations. With NGES, employees can access internal and external RSS feeds within Microsoft Outlook, the full range of mobile devices, corporate portals, and the Web without having to download any client-side software. Enhancements within NGES 1.3 include improvements in usability, integration with Microsoft Sharepoint, new collaboration capabilities, additional knowledge management and administrative features, and globalization.

"A key business issue facing enterprises today is finding the most effective way to manage the information flow of both external and internal content across their organization," said Robert McCullough, program manager, business applications and commerce, Yankee Group. "RSS has emerged as a viable platform for CIOs and CKOs to provide employees with relevant information and collaboration tools, which can directly impact efficiency and improve productivity. NewsGator Enterprise Server helps enterprises become more efficient by centrally managing subscriptions, deploying across platforms without installing client software, and minimizing bandwidth usage."

As companies and employees struggle with information overload, RSS has quickly become a powerful business tool to help them gain control over how content is managed and distributed throughout the organization. Access to accurate and relevant information is critical to making the right business decisions and communicating with customers in a timely manner. Companies in several industries, including pharmaceutical, retail, legal, consulting, human resources, financial services and public relations have dramatically improved employee productivity by deploying NewsGator’s enterprise-focused RSS solutions.

"A lot of valuable, timely information gets lost in email," said Elizabeth Ellis, partner and Chief Knowledge Officer at Toronto based law firm Goodman and Carr, LLP. "With NewsGator Enterprise Server, practice groups can easily see relevant feeds from blogs, news and internal systems on our Microsoft Sharepoint Portal. It allows the attorneys and paralegals to find information more quickly, which will lead to more billable hours and better client service."

"With the rapid growth of both internal and external feeds, companies are quickly realizing that the management and distribution of that content should be handled on a centralized basis," said J.B. Holston, president and CEO of NewsGator. "By working closely with customers since the initial unveiling of NewsGator Enterprise Server last fall, we have improved the knowledge management, collaboration, and administrative tools and added significant functional enhancements that enable businesses to quickly improve productivity and the delivery of information throughout their organizations."

New Features

NewsGator Enterprise Server 1.3 includes the following new capabilities:

Knowledge Management and Relevancy

  • SharePoint Team Portal integration – This feature enables the publishing of a set of feeds to a Microsoft SharePoint portal site that members of a group can view.
  • Group Clippings – This knowledge management feature allows a member of an internal team or group to take important items, add a comment, and drop them into a folder, which is then turned into an RSS feed to which others can subscribe. This increases productivity by enabling many to benefit from the work and effort undertaken by an individual.
  • Refined article and feed searching – Users can customize searches for only internally generated/published content (versus all content indexed internally) and define SmartFeeds (keyword searches) in the same way.
  • Feed creation from email – Users can easily turn emails into RSS feeds.
  • Improved user interface – New look and feel, improved navigation and support for favicons (icons from feed publishers).

Administration

  • Directory servers – Read and manage groups from multiple directory servers.
  • Proxy scripting – The ability to dynamically determine proxy information and multiple URLs as internal (and not to be accessed through proxy).
  • Taxonomy management – Taxonomy editing through UI – Administrators can add and delete categories to the taxonomy (categories of feeds) and feeds to categories through the user interface and also add secure feeds which subscribers can access by entering credentials.

Globalization

  • Localization – Allows organizations to customize the software for foreign languages.

Pricing and Availability

NewsGator Enterprise Server 1.3 is currently available and priced on a per-user basis.

entry.title: NewsGator Launches New Version of Premier Desktop RSS Aggregator NetNewsWire for Mac OS X
entry.summary:
NetNewsWire 2.1 Delivers Several Enhancements in Performance and Function and Integration with NewsGator Online

Denver, CO – May 10, 2006 – NewsGator Technologies, Inc., the leading RSS platform company, today announced the release of an enhanced version of NetNewsWire, the market-leading RSS aggregator for Mac OS X. NetNewsWire 2.1 features extensive performance enhancements, universal binary support for Intel-based Macs, synchronization with the NewsGator Online platform, and a number of additional customer-requested features.

This marks the first new release of the product since NewsGator’s acquisition of NetNewsWire developer Ranchero Software in October of 2005. First released in 2002, NetNewsWire’s usability, deep feature set and continuous innovation have generated widespread adoption by Mac users. The online synchronization in NetNewsWire 2.1 allows users to work seamlessly between the rich Mac desktop application, the web-based NewsGator Online, the PC-based FeedDemon, the recently announced NewsGator Mobile applications, and other NewsGator Online-enabled clients to access RSS content.

"RSS is truly a transformative technology that is quickly reaching the masses because of how effectively it helps people manage news and information," said Brent Simmons, NetNewsWire creator, and NewsGator client product architect. "NetNewsWire users have often asked that their feeds and read/unread status go where they go, from office to home and place to place. By integrating NetNewsWire and NewsGator Online, users can now move easily between our feature-rich desktop products as well as our flexible, web-based solution. Our mission is to make it as easy as possible for Mac users to get all the productivity benefits RSS offers."

New features in NetNewsWire 2.1 include:

• Synchronization with the leading online RSS platform – Seamless synchronization of subscriptions and "read" status with NewsGator Online, so articles marked as "read" on NetNewsWire will show up as read on NewsGator Online, NewsGator Inbox, NewsGator Mobile, FeedDemon, and any other product that uses the NewsGator Online API;

• Universal binary – NetNewsWire 2.1 runs natively on both PowerPC and Intel Macs;

• Performance enhancements – Improvements to feed parsing and processing, saving feed information, and tabbed browsing make for a snappier reading experience;

• Sorting subscriptions by attention – Now you can sort your feeds by what you pay the most (and the least) amount of attention to – perfect for finding information that is relevant to you; and,

• Post to del.icio.us – New command allows you to send posts to del.icio.us using your choice of application.

"The best part about NetNewsWire is that it syncs with NewsGator Online," said Om Malik, senior writer for Business 2.0 and editor of the popular GigaOm blog. "That is crucial, because I have multiple computers and tend to use them at different times of the day. NetNewsWire 2.1 exceeds my expectations from a synchronization and performance perspective."

"NetNewsWire is a great example of what a Macintosh application should be: user-focused, innovative, logical, fast," said Dave Nanian, founder of Shirt Pocket. "Its new NewsGator synchronization means your feeds (and read status) are available wherever you are — home, office, on the road — and so much faster than before that you'll be tempted to subscribe to a lot more feeds."

Pricing and Availability

NetNewsWire 2.1 is available for $29.95 and can be purchased at www.newsgator.com.

Existing NetNewsWire customers will receive a free two-year paid subscription to NewsGator Online.
